title: Kuma's Hidden Agenda and Connection to Dragon
theory: Despite being ordered by the World Government to eliminate all witnesses to Moria's defeat, Kuma seems to have a hidden agenda. Earlier episodes showed Kuma mentioning that Dragon raised a fine son, hinting at a connection to Luffy's father. Fans theorize that Kuma is secretly working with or sympathetic to the Revolutionary Army, and his actions throughout Thriller Bark (offering the ultimatum rather than immediately killing everyone, and his later actions in Episode 377) suggest he's not truly loyal to the World Government despite being a Warlord.
author: One Piece fan community (2008-2009)

spoilerWarning.spoilerDescription: Theory is validated in later arcs when Kuma's connection to the Revolutionary Army is fully revealed

evidence: Kuma's comment about Dragon raising a fine son (Episode 377)
His willingness to offer an ultimatum rather than immediately attack
His enigmatic behavior throughout the arc

title: The True Power Limit of Nikyu Nikyu no Mi
theory: After seeing Kuma repel attacks, air, and create the devastating Ursus Shock, fans began theorizing about the true limits of the Nikyu Nikyu no Mi. Some theorized that if Kuma can repel tangible and intangible things like air and attacks, he might be able to repel even more abstract concepts like pain, fatigue, or memories. This theory gained traction when fans noticed the incredible versatility of the fruit and wondered what else could be 'repelled.'
author: One Piece theory communities (2008-2009)
platform: Forums and early anime discussion boards

spoilerWarning.spoilerDescription: Theory is confirmed in the very next episode when Kuma demonstrates the ability to repel pain and fatigue

evidence: Kuma's statement that he can repel 'anything'
The demonstration of repelling both tangible (objects) and intangible (air) things
The seemingly limitless applications of his Devil Fruit power

title: World Government's Fear of Warlord System Collapse
theory: Kuma's mission to eliminate all witnesses to Moria's defeat reveals that the World Government is deeply concerned about the perception of the Seven Warlords system. Fans theorized that the Warlords are more important for propaganda and political balance than actual strength, and that the system is fragile. Multiple Warlord defeats (Crocodile in Alabasta, now Moria) could cause pirates to lose fear of the system and the Marines to lose a crucial tool for maintaining the balance of power. This theory suggested the World Government would go to extreme lengths to preserve the Warlord system's reputation.
author: One Piece political analysis fans (2008)

spoilerWarning.spoilerDescription: Theory elements are explored further during the Paramount War arc when the Warlord system's importance and fragility are further examined

evidence: Kuma's explicit statement about eliminating witnesses to protect the Warlord reputation
Previous defeat of Warlord Crocodile being covered up by the World Government
The extreme measure of sending a Warlord to kill all witnesses including civilians

title: Ursus Shock as a Forbidden or Last Resort Technique
theory: Some fans theorized that Ursus Shock, given its catastrophic island-destroying power, might be considered a forbidden technique or one that Kuma only uses as a last resort. The theory suggested that using such a devastating attack might have significant drawbacks, physical toll, or energy cost that wasn't immediately apparent in the episode. The fact that Kuma creates such a massive attack just to eliminate relatively weak targets seemed excessive unless he wanted to ensure no one survived or if the technique had limitations on frequency of use.
author: Power-scaling focused fans (2008)

spoilerWarning.spoilerDescription: Speculation about technique limitations and costs

evidence: The extreme destructive power of Ursus Shock
Kuma's deliberate and careful preparation of the technique
The seeming overkill of using such power against already exhausted opponents
